awd_titl_txt: Searches for Exotic Spin-Dependent Forces using High-Frequency Mechanical Oscillators
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports an experimental search for fundamental forces of nature beyond gravity and electromagnetism at sub-millimeter length scales.  Forces could depend on several properties of the test objects involved, such as mass (like gravity), or charge (like electromagnetism).  The proposed experiments concentrate on forces that depend on spin, which can be thought of as the rotation of an object around its axis. Most subatomic particles (including the protons, neutrons, and electrons of ordinary matter) have non-zero spin, which determines their magnetic properties: magnetic forces depend on spin.  The discovery of an additional macroscopic force that depends on spin would have enormous implications for physics from subatomic to cosmological scales.  A variety of extensions to the Standard Model (the most successful theory of particle physics to date, but widely believed to be incomplete) predict short-range spin-dependent forces.  These forces are mediated by particles that could contribute to "dark matter," the otherwise unknown quantity hypothesized to make up about one quarter of the mass of the universe and to explain the apparent mass distributions of galaxies. During its execution, this fundamental project will also provide all participants (including undergraduates who have contributed to this proposal) with experience in mechanical design, vacuum technology, low-noise electronics, semiconductor and magnetic materials processing, and other practical techniques useful in a wide range of science and engineering fields.  The experiment will also be a key focus of the Indiana University Center for Spacetime Symmetries (IUCSS), which was founded by the PI and his colleagues to strengthen and publicize IU's growing expertise in the investigation of the structure of spacetime.

The experiment uses 1-kilohertz planar oscillators as test masses with a thin shield between them to suppress backgrounds, a technique that has demonstrated the capability to probe micron-scale distances using relatively large (square-centimeter) masses, and to operate at the limit of instrumental thermal noise at room temperature.  The principal challenge will be to overcome the anticipated magnetic backgrounds associated with the use of polarized test masses.  To this end we have developed spin-polarized test masses with very low intrinsic magnetism. We will use them in our experiments to conduct initial searches for several velocity-independent spin-coupled forces with unprecedented sensitivity below one millimeter, and to search for several more velocity-dependent interactions that are presently unconstrained by experiment. We will also investigate polarized materials that have the potential to improve our experimental sensitivity by several additional orders of magnitude. At the completion of the award period, it is our expectation that, in the absence of a discovery, we will have set limits on as many as eleven previously unconstrained spin-coupled interactions of electrons in the sub-millimeter range, and up to four more limits with sensitivity at least order of magnitude greater than present constraints.

por.por_cntn:
Newton's law of gravity states that the force between two objects is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.  This law is termed "universal," that is, true for all length scales, but this is an experimental question.  Newton's law has been tested down to length scales of forty microns, with no evidence of any deviation.  However, there could be forces of nature millions of times stronger than gravity acting below this range, for which we have no experimental evidence. There is ample motivation to search for such forces. Theories developed over the past few decades to account for gravity's weakness, unify it with the other forces of nature, and explain the mysterious "dark matter" and "dark energy" thought to pervade all of space, all make predictions of forces beyond gravity and electromagnetism in the sub-millimeter range.  Like gravity, these forces could depend on the masses of the test objects, or, like magnetism, they could depend on another fundamental property of elementary particles: spin, which can be thought of as an intrinsic rotation.  The intellectual merit of our project, experiments to search for exotic spin-dependent and mass-dependent forces below 1 millimeter, derives from its sensitivity to these forces.  It also derives from the technique, which uses a novel material to suppress large magnetic backgrounds. This material, dysprosium iron garnet (DyIG), contains two magnetic components.  One (iron) has the high spin content necessary for the experiments.  At a specific temperature, magnetism associated with the iron spins is cancelled by that of the orbital motion of the electrons (which is essentially macroscopic and thus ordinary) in the dysprosium.  In previous work, we measured high aligned-spin density in this material with no detectable magnetism at a "compensation" temperature of about -50 Celsius.

Over the four-year cycle ending in August 2021, our experiments received support from the National Science Foundation. During this period our accomplishments included:

  • Construction of a complete apparatus for a spin-dependent force search.  This includes a set of test masses augmented with a samples of DyIG.  It also includes a cooling system, consisting of a shell with hollow walls surrounding the test masses on the sides and top.  The shell is filled with liquid nitrogen and the masses are cooled radiatively to about -60 Celsius; a heater warms the system precisely to the compensation temperature.  Finally it includes a set of coils centered on the test masses, to produce a magnetic force to drive the test masses as the temperature is lowered.  Attainment of the compensation temperature is inferred when the magnetic response is minimized.
  • Successful operation of the complete apparatus. Test mass response to the magnetic drive was monitored as the system was cooled.  The signal decreased to nearly zero at -49.3 Celsius, below which it reversed in sign and began to increase in magnitude; the definitive signature of the compensation temperature. The limiting background in the experiment, the noise due to the random thermal motion of the test masses (corresponding to a force of about one millionth of one billionth of a pound), was also measured at the lowest temperatures, confirming operation of the experiment over the complete temperature range.
  • An improved test of Einstein's principle of relativity, which states essentially that physical laws are independent of the orientation or speed of observers. This principle lies at the heart of currently accepted theories of gravity and quantum mechanics, but may actually impede the unification of these theories.  Work by Indiana University colleagues shows how tiny relativity violations lead to skewed, inverse sixth power corrections to the gravitational inverse square law.  In an analysis developed with collaborators at Indiana and the Huazhong University of Science and Technology in China, we used previous data from our experiment to establish the strongest-ever constraints on these corrections.

The broader impact of the project begins locally with the direct involvement of students, including undergraduates, in all aspects of the experiments. While our experiments are fundamental in nature, the students of all levels who work on them learn techniques of mechanical design, vacuum systems, low-noise electronics, cryogenics, and semiconductor and magnetic materials processing, thus gaining leverage for finding academic and industrial positions.  The project provided complete support for one graduate student throughout its duration, and produced the material for one doctoral dissertation.  The project supported three undergraduate research assistants, one of whom has been admitted to nine top physics graduate programs, and another of whom is employed full time as a high school math and science instructor.

Our work has been a focus of the Indiana Center for Spacetime Symmetries (IUCSS), co-founded by the principal investigator to strengthen and publicize Indiana's growing expertise in the investigation of the structure of spacetime. Through the work of the center, our work on relativity tests motivated similar searches by other groups on the international level.
